Habitat Description
The Hoary Marmot (Marmota caligata) is limited to alpine and subalpine mountain slopes (Barash 1989), although the minimum elevation at which this species occurs decreases as you move north through its range; it can be found at sea level in Alaska but is only found in alpine and subalpine mountain slopes further south (Barash 1989).  It inhabits systems ranging from semiarid alpine to rich stream beds including talus, scree, alpine meadows, rocky outcrops, subalpine meadows, and herbaceous grasslands (Barash 1989, NatureServe 2014). 
Hoary and Yellow-bellied Marmots appear to displace one another in areas of where their ranges overlap (e.g., Purcell and Flint Creek Ranges in Montana); Yellow-bellied Marmots occupy lower elevations while Hoary Marmots occupy high elevations.  In parts of northern Wyoming and southern Montana, Hoary Marmots are absent at the higher elevation sites and they are therefore occupied by Yellow-bellied Marmots.  N. Tarr, 19March2014.
